Award.AwardTitle: CRII: Cyberlearning: Lived Science Narratives: Meaningful Elementary Science through Wearable Technologies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A key goal of the Next Generation Science Standards is to shift the focus of science instruction away from the classroom and out into the world. This research aims to extend what students learn in their science classes beyond the formal context of the school. The project will investigate an approach whereby students will be encouraged to think critically about how science is present and applicable in their daily life experiences through the use of smartwatches. The approach consists of three main parts. First, students will use smartwatches to voice-record observations related to a science topic in their everyday lives. Second, students will be able to reflect on their "lived science stories" and edit them into fuller narratives via a web interface, thus contributing to their language arts learning. Third, the students' science stories will be presented to the school teacher via a web application that will help that teacher to diagnose and correct their misconceptions and make science teaching more relevant and meaningful in the classroom. This work could have lasting benefits to society, not only in terms of the support of children's engagement and interest in STEM topics but also in the practice of listening, reading and writing at a critical period of their development.

A server-based system will be designed that integrates (1) a smartwatch interface for children to audio-record science stories, (2) a web-based storytelling interface to allow them to transcribe and edit their audio story snippets, and (3) a web-based instructional support interface in the form of a curation board that draws together the students' edited science stories for the teacher. The project will employ an iterative design methodology to develop the lived-stories interfaces and test them for usability. A school study will be conducted in two 4th-grade science classes over two science topics at an elementary school with a high percentage of students from populations typically underrepresented in STEM fields. The same science classes will be taught with and without the lived-science narrative technology in a counterbalanced experimental design. Pre-/post-test quizzes, interviews, self-report questionnaires, and video-based analysis will be used to assess whether and how the lived-stories approach may enhance not only students' understanding of science concepts and their motivation to study science but also the teacher's instructional strategies. This project will advance our understanding of how children's narrative way of thinking about their everyday embodied experiences may be used to scaffold their understanding of science concepts gained from formal instruction. The research will also contribute knowledge on the design of novel instructional strategies for elementary science teaching that are anchored in students' personal experiences as well as guidelines and technical frameworks for the design of wearables to support science learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lived Science Narratives is an NSF-funded project that investigated how to contextualize the learning of elementary science topics with children's everyday experiences through the use of wearables, specifically the smartwatch. Requirements of universal mass education have led to the contemporary model of instruction where students find it challenging to understand the relevance of learning content to their own lives. Within the bounded setting of the classroom, educators attempt to make up for this loss of context in instruction by using various strategies, such as drawing from their own life experiences to provide real-life scenario examples in their teaching, asking students to bring in stimulus materials from home, or organizing field trips. This project explored the potential of using commodity wearables, specifically the smartwatch, that are easily available to instructors and schools to help contextualize the learning of elementary school science topics.

Overall, through a series of studies, the project made the following contributions: (i) an understanding was obtained of how children use smartwatches in their everyday life to capture science reflections (contexts of use, manner of use, motivation levels, etc.); (ii) a dataset of 583 everyday science reflections covering 7 different science topics (e.g., food chains, ecosystems) from formal school curricula collected through smartwatches by children aged 8 to 11 was obtained. The dataset can be requested for research use by emailing the PI; (iii) we developed a smartwatch app to support everyday science reflections for children; and (iv) implications were derived for designing context-aware wearables for educational reflective use. 

As part of key findings, we uncovered the different types of science reflections that children can produce in their everyday life using smartwatches, and the ways by which they relate their everyday experiences to science concepts. The total set of smartwatch everyday science reflections that a child captures on a specific science concept can reveal the following: the child?s level of conceptual understanding of the science phenomenon (by analyzing what is included in the reflections), the misconceptions that s/he has about the concept (by analyzing inaccuracies in the reflections), and the degree of motivation of the child to engage with science (by number of reflections done). 

Gamified smartwatch app designs produce reflections of satisfactory quality (based on relevance to science concept) and lead to the largest number of average reflections per child, as compared to narrative and hybrid versions. We were also able to characterize the types of contexts in which children made use of the smartwatch for science reflections, and developed a model indicating the various factors that influence such use. That model led us to conclude that children have two modes of engagement with smartwatches for educational reflexive use: (a) in the primary mode of engagement, although the science reflection prompt (through the smartwatch) and real-world activities are ever present and always happening, reflections are captured only when there is a ?break? in real-life activities (e.g., waiting for a friend to arrive); and (b) in the secondary mode of engagement, real-life experiences lead the child to think about the science prompt through serendipitous connections (e.g., seeing a dog and thinking of the concept of inherited and learned traits).

And finally, with respect to an adult population, our studies uncovered that users engage in different micro-behavioral patterns of interaction depending on the form factor of a wearable, and that people are generally positive towards the use of wearables for learning support. 

For a complete list of related publications and to read more about the project, visit https://elxlab.cise.ufl.edu/research/lived-science-narratives/
